t: Do*pn you think it is just when you say, “I*ln am righteous before God”?
For*ln you ask, “What does it profit you, and*ln what benefit comes to me, if I do not sin?”
I*ln will answer you and*ln your friends with you.
Look*ln at the heavens and see; gaze*ln at the clouds high above you.
If*ln you sin, how does it affect God? If*ln you multiply your transgressions, what does it do to him?
If*ln you are righteous, what do you give him, or*ln what does he receive from your hand?
Your*ln wickedness affects a person like yourself, and*ln your righteousness, a son of man.
People*ln cry out because of severe oppression; they*ln shout for help because of the power of the mighty.
But*ln no one asks, “Where is God my Maker, who*ln provides us with songs in the night,
who*ln gives us more understanding than the animals of the earth and*ln makes us wiser than the birds of the sky?”
There*ln they cry out, but he does not answer, because*ln of the pride of evil people.
Indeed,*ln God does not listen to empty cries, and*ln the Almighty does not take note of it —
how*ln much less when you complain that*ln you do not see him, that*ln your case is before him and*ln you are waiting for him.
But*ln now, because God’s anger does not punish and*ln he does not pay attention to transgression,
Job*ln opens his mouth in vain and*ln multiplies words without knowledge.
